thread.title: Non-traditional church works to revive Miramichi 1 building at a time
thread.title_full: Non-traditional church works to revive Miramichi 1 building at a time

author: cbc
title: Non-traditional church works to revive Miramichi 1 building at a time
text:
A small church with big ideas is helping bring life back into a once depressed corner on Miramichi's east side.
Victor Somers says when he moved back to the city six years ago he wanted to do more than start a church.
"I thought if we could put our resources into bringing life back to that one corner of the city, I thought we would be doing the city some good," he said.
EastSide Church purchased two vacant buildings on opposite corners of Cunard and Wellington streets in the former town of Chatham.
One of them is the Vogue Theatre, a building Somers said felt like a time capsule when he walked inside five years ago.
The former movie theatre still had candy on the shelves and film on the reels in the projector room from when it closed in 2000.
But rather than seeing a neglected, rundown building, Somers saw the potential to open a church and have a building that could be used by the community.
Non-traditional church "One of the ideas we had was rather than building a traditional church building that would only serve those who just show up to [church] services or programs, we would find a building that everyone already loved and bring it back," he said.
After a renovation project that saw the auditorium completely refurbished, the Vogue Theatre was reopened.
"It's a nice mid-size venue for the city and has all the modern amenities that you would need," said Somers.
The lights on the Vogue Theatre sign are on again after the EastSide Church bought and reopened the building after extensive renovations. (Vogue Theatre/Facebook)
The 320-seat theatre now hosts popular musical acts, local theatre, Theatre New Brunswick productions, documentaries, comedy shows and more.
A recently formed board of directors will help promote the venue. Somers admits it's taken time to make some realize the theatre can operate as both a church and theatre.
"We really are here to promote the city and to help Miramichi be a healthy community and a vibrant community as well with lots of culture."
Somers says there were times during the renovation when he questioned if he'd made the right choice to buy it and pull the project off.
Giving back A small group worked to keep the 1950s feel but had to completely refurbish the 4,000-square foot auditorium with new flooring, new seating, a fresh coat of paint and more. Somers said all the work was done by volunteers and donations.
Somers deliberately left some things untouched and says he enjoys seeing the reactions when people visit the Vogue again for the first time.
"They notice it is very much like the way they remember it," said Somers.
That includes a broken clock on the wall the previous owner had never fixed.
Victor Somers is not only a pastor, but does many jobs for his church including being a barista in the Creative Grounds Café. (Creative Grounds Cafe/Faceboook)
"I didn't touch it, I left it there. It's still stuck at quarter to seven," said Somers.
Across the street, they've opened the Creative Grounds Café in the front section of a sprawling 19,000-square foot building.
Other parts of the building are being used by a community arts school, dance school, mixed martial arts school and more.
Somers has more ideas to make use of the remaining space and ways to continue to include the community.
"I am taking what I know and what I do to help build the community back up," he said.
EastSide Church has given life to two vacant buildings on Miramichi's east side of the city in the former town of Chatham. (EastSide Church/Facebook)
